1Or *the Hebrew dialect* (probably Aramaic) 2Or *the Hebrew dialect* (probably Aramaic) 3Or *city at the feet of Gamaliel, educated* 4Or *hear with understanding* 5Or *when they had tied him up with leather strips*

#### *Section Overview: Paul Addresses the Mob in Jerusalem*

This section, straddling Acts 21 and 22, is devoted to Paul's speech before the hostile Jews in Jerusalem. He first recounts briefly his personal history in Judaism, summing it up in two major periods. He was trained by Gamaliel and zealous for the law and for God and then became a persecutor of Christians. These two periods are linked, as they are in Paul's description of his spiritual background in Philippians 3.

Paul then moves on to describing his Damascus road experience. At the center is his encounter with the risen Jesus, "whom you are persecuting" (Acts 22:8). Paul recounts that he was not alone when he encountered Jesus, and even though his companions neither saw Jesus nor understood what he said to Paul, they did see the light surrounding Jesus and later took Paul to Damascus.

The next section (vv. 12–16) recounts Paul's meeting Ananias. He specifically points out that he was a "devout man according to the law," with a good reputation among his fellow Jews. Through Ananias, Paul regained his sight and received revelation about his calling. Jesus is identified as "the Righteous One," an explicit description of his identity as Messiah. Through the name of Jesus, Paul's sins were forgiven.

Next Paul reveals a revelation he received during his visit to Jerusalem (narrated in chapter 9). Paul's mission to the Gentiles was revealed to him from the beginning of his ministry.

Enraged by the mention of Gentiles, the crowd calls for his death, and the Roman tribune takes Paul to be beaten. Once again Paul exercises his rights as a Roman citizen, and once again he is saved from death by secular authorities.

# *Section Outline*

II.C. Paul Addresses the Mob in Jerusalem (21:37–22:29)

- 1. Paul's Request to Speak (21:37–39)
- 2. Paul Testifies to His Conversion and Calling (21:40–22:29)

### *Comment*

21:37–39 *Paul's Request to Speak.* Historically speaking, the followers of the Way were merely a minor sect of Judaism, which itself was hardly the center of attention in the Roman Empire. During the first century, only Jews and Christians understood the massive difference between themselves. Thus it should not surprise us that the Roman tribune does not know who Paul is and assumes he must be a certain infamous Jew from Egypt who had led four thousand terrorists (v. 38). The Assassins were a particular sect known as the Sicarii, "dagger-men." The tribune is surprised to know that Paul speaks Greek—perhaps indicating that Judean Jews did not typically speak Greek—but he sees that there is more to Paul than meets the eye, and he allows Paul to speak.

21:40–22:29 *Paul Testifies to His Conversion and Calling.* Paul immediately wins the crowd's attention by stepping up, motioning to them, and speaking to them in Aramaic (22:2; "the Hebrew language" means the language of the Hebrews, which had been Aramaic for a long time). Luke notes that this quiets the crowd even more. Paul addresses them as "brothers and fathers," showing his respect for them and underscoring their shared covenantal heritage (22:1).

Paul begins by describing his background before narrating his conversion. His testimony here differs in some details from the account in chapter 9, which is Luke's retelling of the event, while this is the testimony of Paul himself. The apostle's summary of his Jewish background and experience as a persecutor of the church is reminiscent of Philippians 3:4–6; here Paul adds that he was taught by Gamaliel—the same Gamaliel that spoke up and urged the council to show caution in their treatment of Peter and the apostles (Acts 5:34–39). The "strict manner of the law" (22:3) refers to the Pharisaic tradition in which Paul was trained. He is letting his listeners know that he is one of them and, in fact, outdoes most of them in his Jewish pedigree. He is an expert in the law, something they should keep in mind when they charge him with breaking it.

As in Philippians 3, Paul links his former persecution of the church with his zealous background. In Philippians this link serves to show the false zeal and righteousness from the law that Paul relied on before his conversion. That idea is likely present here too, but his main purpose is to tell the crowd that he was once standing where they are now when he persecuted Christians before his conversion. If they do not believe him, the Jewish elders, including the high priest, can validate his claim, because he was working for them the day Jesus appeared to him on the road to Damascus (Acts 22:5). The irony here is that just as Paul now stands before them in custody, so he himself once set out for Damascus to arrest Christians and "bring them in bonds to Jerusalem to be punished."

The "great light from heaven" (22:6) indicates the presence of God, a detail hardly missed by his Jewish audience, as God's presence revealed in visible light of various kinds occurred throughout Israel's history. Such revelations of God in light are particularly connected with, though not limited to, major covenantal events (e.g., Gen. 15:17; Ex. 3:2–3; 19:18; see also Ex. 13:21–22; 14:24; Num. 14:14). In a covenantal context, a voice speaking out of light recalls Deuteronomy 5:24, where Moses recalled the experience of God's revelation at Sinai. This time, the voice coming out of the light is the Lord Jesus. Paul's description of his conversion, read against its larger biblical background, strongly suggests the divinity of Jesus, for Jesus spoke to him just as Yahweh spoke to Moses and the Israelites.

As in Acts 9:4 and later in 26:14, persecuting Christians means persecuting Jesus: the people of Jesus are his body. The differences in the experience of Paul's companions in the account in chapter 9 and Paul's version here are easily reconciled. Acts 9:7 describes them "hearing the voice" but "seeing no one," whereas in 22:9 they "saw the light" but could not "understand the voice." They heard the sound of the voice but did not understand what was being said. They perceived the light but saw no one speaking to Paul. None of the accounts of Paul's conversion in Acts (chs. 9; 22; 26) ever mentions Paul seeing a human form on the Damascus road—only that he saw a light and heard a voice. The conversion accounts are remarkably similar and contain no discrepancies. The differences in detail are simply due to the differences in the way humans tell stories, depending on the occasion and reason for the telling. The main reason Luke and Paul mention the traveling companions is to point to eyewitnesses who can confirm the event (Deut. 19:15; Matt. 18:16; 2 Cor. 13:1; 1 Tim. 5:19; Heb. 10:28).

Paul fills in further detail concerning his encounter with Ananias. The account in Acts 9 highlights Ananias's caution and hesitancy over Paul, in keeping with the emphasis of growth through persecution in that portion of the narrative. This version focuses more directly on Paul's experience of God's revelation to him in Jesus and his commission to be a witness for Christ. Paul points out that Ananias was a "devout man according to the law," with a good reputation (22:12). This underscores the legitimacy of Paul's story and also provides yet another level of confirmation: if there is any lingering doubt about the divine encounter from heaven and the voice Paul heard, the recounting of Ananias's word to Paul removes it. Ananias tells Paul what the Lord directed him to communicate in 9:11–16, with more detail added. Paul recounts how Ananias explained the experience as nothing less than an encounter with their covenant God, who revealed the promised Messiah ("the Righteous One"; 22:14) and appointed Paul as his witness.

Any question of whether Paul was converted or simply put on the right road to becoming a truly faithful Jew in acceptance of Jesus as Messiah is answered unequivocally in this text. Ananias instructed Paul to be baptized in the name of Jesus for the forgiveness of sins (22:16). The message for Saul, a law-abiding Pharisee who at one point lived to kill Christians, is the same as Peter's answer to those gathered on Pentecost: "Repent and be baptized every one of you in the name of Jesus Christ for the forgiveness of your sins" (2:38).

Common threads tie conversion in Acts to Paul's experience. Soon after Pentecost, standing before the Jewish rulers, Peter declares, "There is salvation in no one else, for there is no other name under heaven given among men by which we must be saved" (4:12). Though Ananias did not say "be saved," he did say "wash away your sins" (22:16), another way of referring to salvation. The same sort of language associated with coming to faith in Jesus, being converted from either Jewish or Gentile unbelief (16:31), in the name of Jesus, is exactly the kind of language Paul recounts when he relates his own testimony. This is not a story of getting on some sort of journey with God; it is an account of a sinner saved through the name of Jesus.

Paul continues by revealing previously undisclosed events (22:17–19). His trance in the temple almost certainly occurred during his first trip to Jerusalem as a believer (ch. 9). The temple, though its time in redemptive history is over, remains a focal point for Christians in Jerusalem. However, there is no particular link between Paul's receiving a direct word from the Lord and his being in the temple. With this exception, every special revelation Paul receives occurs outside Jerusalem. If one thing is clear from Acts, it is that God is at work seemingly everywhere but inside the temple in Jerusalem.

But the fact that Paul's vision and his word from the Lord occurred in the temple would be of importance to his Jewish audience. The temple is precisely the place where one might receive a word from God. More importantly, the Jews accuse Paul of speaking against the temple (21:28). Like the other apostles, Paul does not speak against the temple. They do, however, teach that the presence of God is not limited to, and no longer resides in, the temple. God does not live in man-made buildings, and the old covenant era, and therefore the temple, has come to a close with the fulfillment of God's promises in Jesus the Messiah. In fact, venerating the Jerusalem temple is a form of idolatry. Paul and the other apostles hear from God anywhere and everywhere—in jail cells (5:19–20), on rooftops (10:9–20), and while traveling far from Jerusalem and the temple (13:2). It is through the apostles that the Lord speaks to those who believe in the Messiah, Jesus. The temple and all that took place there are, like the priests and the leaders of Israel, eclipsed by Jesus.

This is not the only depiction in Acts of an apostle falling into a trance. Peter had a similar experience on the rooftop in Joppa, where he saw a vision of animals on a sheet (10:10–16). That vision revealed how everything was now clean to eat, the ultimate significance being that the Gentiles, beginning with Cornelius, were to be fully accepted and included in the new covenant people of God. Similarly, the word of the Lord to Paul while in a trance at the temple is that his mission would be to the Gentiles. We take it for granted that the Gentiles are fully included; at the outset, however, it took special revelation (as well as many years of evidence, controversy, setbacks, and perseverance) to reach that point.

Paul never forgot his former role as persecutor of the church (Gal. 1:13–14; Phil. 3:6; 1 Tim. 1:13). He viewed himself as an unworthy latecomer, the least of all the apostles, "because I persecuted the church of God" (1 Cor. 15:9). In the early days he was, understandably, concerned with what Christians would think of him. The former persecutor who wanted believers dead was now preaching the gospel (Gal. 1:23). He was also apparently aware of what his former Jewish colleagues would think of him. When the Lord warned him to leave Jerusalem because the Jews would not listen to him (Acts 22:18), Paul responded in a way that sounded like he knew exactly why they would reject him: they would think him a hypocrite. Paul replied, in effect, "Of course they will reject me, and I will tell you why: I used to be one of them when I was hunting down your people, and I cheered on those who killed Stephen" (cf. 22:19–20).

Paul recounts these events especially because his former life played a providential role in his becoming the apostle to the Gentiles—and, subsequently, in his ending up in custody in Jerusalem. The Lord, like Paul, knew that Jerusalem and Israel generally were not Paul's best field of mission in light of his former public life as a persecutor. So Paul went to the Gentiles instead (22:21). It is his ministry among and with Gentiles that has led to the accusations against him. Paul began by persecuting the church; after his conversion he became the apostle to the Gentiles, and largely because of his ministry among the Gentiles he is persecuted by the Jews. Paul tells his accusers plainly that not only did the Lord speak to him; the Lord is the one behind his ministry to the Gentiles.

Paul's mention of his ministry to the Gentiles is more than the crowds can stand. Their verdict is clear: Paul must die (22:22). They work themselves into a frenzy, taking off their cloaks and throwing around dust. These are strange reactions to us but were expressions of lament, condemnation, and anger in that cultural context (22:23). The tribune seeks to defuse the crowd, but his primary goal is to get the truth out of Paul by beating him. Once again, however, Paul's Roman citizenship saves the day (cf. 16:37–40). It is illegal to beat a Roman citizen without a trial and a judgment of guilt. The tribune and soldiers understand the consequences of unlawfully beating a Roman citizen, and so they back off.

#### *Response*

This narrative puts God's providence in sustaining Paul and fulfilling his purpose for Paul on display. The Jewish crowd is in a frenzy to kill Paul as a covenant breaker and traitor against Israel. The mob shows no sign of conscience regarding how to question and judge Paul according to covenant law (much like Jesus before the council). A Roman tribune, no friend of the Jews, gets Paul away from his Jewish countrymen in order to find out, by torture, exactly what is going on. Then, just as a Roman centurion is about to interrogate him with a whipping, Paul asserts his Roman citizenship and gets off without a scratch. And all of this takes place because the Messiah, the Lord Jesus of Nazareth, revealed himself to Saul, the persecutor of the church, in a way that clearly alluded to the revelation of God in the OT. This same Lord would later speak to Paul again and commission him as his witness to the Gentiles. No one, apart from God in his wisdom, would come up with such a plan.

**<sup>6</sup>**Now when Paul perceived that one part were Sadducees and the other Pharisees, he cried out in the council, "Brothers, I am a Pharisee, a son of Pharisees. It is with respect to the hope and the resurrection of the dead that I am on trial." **7**And when he had said this, a dissension arose between the Pharisees and the Sadducees, and the assembly was divided. **<sup>8</sup>**For the Sadducees say that there is no resurrection, nor angel, nor spirit, but the Pharisees acknowledge them all. **9**Then a great clamor arose, and some of the scribes of the Pharisees' party stood up and contended sharply, "We find nothing wrong in this man. What if a spirit or an angel spoke to him?" **10**And when the dissension became violent, the tribune, afraid that Paul would be torn to pieces by them, commanded the soldiers to go down and take him away from among them by force and bring him into the barracks.

**<sup>11</sup>**The following night the Lord stood by him and said, "Take courage, for as you have testified to the facts about me in Jerusalem, so you must testify also in Rome."

**<sup>12</sup>**When it was day, the Jews made a plot and bound themselves by an oath neither to eat nor drink till they had killed Paul. **13**There were more than forty who made this conspiracy. **14**They went to the chief priests and elders and said, "We have strictly bound ourselves by an oath to taste no food till we have killed Paul. **15**Now therefore you, along with the council, give notice to the tribune to bring him down to you, as though you were

going to determine his case more exactly. And we are ready to kill him before he comes near."

And now they are ready, waiting for your consent." **<sup>22</sup>** So the tribune dismissed the young man, charging him, "Tell no one that you have informed me of these things."

**23**Then he called two of the centurions and said, "Get ready two hundred soldiers, with seventy horsemen and two hundred spearmen to go as far as Caesarea at the third hour of the night.*<sup>1</sup>* **<sup>24</sup>**Also provide mounts for Paul to ride and bring him safely to Felix the governor." **25**And he wrote a letter to this effect:

**<sup>26</sup>** "Claudius Lysias, to his Excellency the governor Felix, greetings. **<sup>27</sup>**This man was seized by the Jews and was about to be killed by them when I came upon them with the soldiers and rescued him, having learned that he was a Roman citizen. **28**And desiring to know the charge for which they were accusing him, I brought him down to their council. **<sup>29</sup>** I found that he was being accused about questions of their law, but charged with nothing deserving death or imprisonment. **30**And when it was disclosed to me that there would be a plot against the man, I sent him to you at once, ordering his accusers also to state before you what they have against him."

**<sup>31</sup>** So the soldiers, according to their instructions, took Paul and brought him by night to Antipatris. **32**And on the next day they returned to the barracks, letting the horsemen go on with him. **33**When they had come to Caesarea and delivered the letter to the governor, they presented Paul also before him. **34**On reading the letter, he asked what province he was from. And when he learned that he was from Cilicia, **35**he said, "I will give you a hearing when your accusers arrive." And he commanded him to be guarded in Herod's praetorium.

1That is, 9 p.m.

#### *Section Overview: Paul's Defense before the Sanhedrin*

The Roman tribune brings Paul to the council in order to find answers regarding the accusations against Paul. Immediately a conflict arises between the high priest (Ananias) and Paul. The priest orders Paul to be struck, and Paul responds by calling him a "whitewashed wall" who does not know the law he is meant to enforce (Acts 23:3). Paul divides the council of Pharisees and Sadducees by mentioning the resurrection, insisting that he is on trial because of his belief in that doctrine. This causes a heated split between the Pharisees, whose scribes find Paul innocent, and the resurrection-denying Sadducees. For the third time in as many chapters, a Roman tribune comes to Paul's rescue.

In collusion with the chief priests and Jewish elders, forty men swear to murder Paul by deceiving the Romans about their intentions (23:12–15). Paul's nephew warns the centurion of the plot, and Paul, under the guard of 470 soldiers, cavalry, and spearmen, is sent to Felix, the current governor of Judea (23:22–24). Felix reads a letter from the tribune concerning Paul and agrees to hear him and his accusers (23:25–35).

#### *Section Outline*

II.D. Paul's Defense before the Sanhedrin (22:30–23:35)

- 1. Paul Speaks to His Accusers (22:30–23:11)
- 2. The Jews Vow to Kill Paul (23:12–35)

# *Comment*

22:30–23:11 *Paul Speaks to His Accusers.* The Roman tribune brings Paul to the priests and the council in order to get to the bottom of the controversy (22:30). His motivation is not so much Paul's best interests as his own. He has just come within an inch of beating a Roman citizen—an offense for which he would certainly have been punished—but he still has a job to do, so he goes looking for answers. It is also in his interests to keep Paul safe, which is what he does when the meeting turns into a melee (23:10). The apostle to the Gentiles is protected from his own countrymen by a Gentile.

Paul goes before the council and says in effect, "I am innocent of whatever charges you might bring. I have done what God has called me to do" (cf. 23:1). Paul is not claiming to be perfect; he is speaking only in regard to his confidence in his calling from God and his faithfulness in carrying out that calling. But Ananias will hear nothing from this perceived traitor of the covenant, the Jewish people, and their traditions. He views Paul as a blasphemer and orders his cronies to punch Paul in the mouth (23:2).

Paul responds by calling Ananias a "whitewashed wall" (23:3). Jesus called the scribes and Pharisees, among many other things, "whitewashed tombs" (Matt. 23:27), and John the Baptist called the Pharisees and Sadducees a "brood of vipers" (Matt. 3:7). John and Jesus stood firmly in a line of faithful Jews who denounced faithless and corrupt Jewish leaders (e.g., Jer. 12:10; Ezek. 34:8, 10; Zech. 10:3). On the other hand Jesus, when standing before his accusers, said nothing in response to abject humiliation, abuse, and savage treatment. Paul himself wrote that "when reviled, we bless; when persecuted, we endure; when slandered, we entreat" (1 Cor. 4:12–13). Thus there appear to be biblical grounds for both of Paul's responses (in Acts 23:3 and 5).

A reasonable interpretation is that Paul erroneously lashes out in strong anger at first, then checks himself upon finding out that Ananias is high priest.

Another possibility, one that is perhaps more persuasive, is that Paul's message for the Jewish leadership is not an insult hurled in anger but a strong word of judgment and condemnation similar to Jesus' words quoted above.91 Paul, taking a bold stand against the hypocrisy and unbelief of the Jewish authorities, speaks a justified word of judgment upon the high priest in a manner similar to the OT prophets, who spoke against the corrupt rulers, priests, and prophets in Israel. Such strong language against those who should be faithful to God and fulfilling their role as shepherds of the people is common in the OT (e.g., Jer. 2:8; 10:21; 23:1–2; Ezek. 34:2–10).

Readers may express surprise that Paul claims not to know that it is Ananias the high priest speaking to him (Acts 23:5). Some scholars argue that Paul had poor eyesight, basing this conclusion on Paul's statement in Galatians 4:15 or his discussion of his "thorn . . . in the flesh" in 2 Corinthians 12:7. Others argue that Paul is speaking ironically: he knows full well that Ananias the high priest was speaking to him but refuses to acknowledge his authority due to the corruption of the priesthood and Ananias's rejection of Paul's message. However, this does not seem to accord with the apostle's citation of Exodus 22:28.92 Still others argue that Paul simply does not know that Ananias is the high priest. He has been away from Jerusalem for a long time, perhaps eight or more years. Possibly he is simply not aware of the current leadership, and Ananias's attire might look no different than anyone else's on the council. This view has the benefit of being the simplest reading and probably the best.

What Paul does next is both clever and shrewd, a stroke of genius. He was once a "Pharisee of Pharisees" (cf. Phil. 3:5) and thus understands the political situation from the inside out. When he realizes there are both Sadducees and Pharisees in the room, he knows exactly how to defuse the situation. The Pharisees were conservative traditionalists who wanted to be free to follow Torah and their own traditions. Though there are exceptions, they are largely criticized and condemned in the NT for their insistence on law keeping without scruples and law keeping apart from devotion or loyalty to God. Jesus identified their OT counterparts as those who killed and persecuted the prophets (Matthew 23). Some of the harshest condemnations in the Bible are aimed at the Pharisees. They did, however, know the law and thoroughly believe in a future resurrection.

The Sadducees were hellenized, wealthy, basically secular Jews who controlled the priesthood and enjoyed political power, at least to the degree that it was granted by those above them in the Roman Empire. In reaching these heights of wealth and privilege, these Sadducees jettisoned many orthodox beliefs, such as belief in the resurrection, angels, or spirits (Acts 23:8; Luke 20:27).

Paul goes straight for the issue that he knows already divides the Pharisees and the Sadducees—the possibility of bodily resurrection. "Some of the scribes of the Pharisees' party" (Acts 23:9) defend Paul less out of a conviction that he is right

<sup>91</sup> Polhill, *Acts*, 468.

<sup>92</sup> Peterson, *Acts*, 614.

and more because of their dislike of the Sadducees, who deny the resurrection that Paul teaches. Thus for a second time (cf. 5:33–40) the Pharisees become unwitting instruments for protecting the gospel. The Roman authorities also continue to protect Paul. The tribune saves Paul from harm when the "dissension" between the Pharisees and the Sadducees becomes "violent" (23:10).

After this tumult, Christ appears to Paul in order to strengthen his resolve, declaring, "Take courage, for as you have testified to the facts about me in Jerusalem, so you must testify also in Rome" (23:11). This confirms Paul's own understanding of his calling, expressed in 19:21, and also echoes Christ's words to Ananias concerning Paul's mission, recorded in 9:15. Regardless of wellintentioned warnings from prophets such as Agabus, pleadings of friends, plots and schemes of the Jews, the force of the entire Roman Empire, or even the power of the sea, the Lord has a mission for Paul, and it will be fulfilled.

23:12–35 *The Jews Vow to Kill Paul.* More than forty men swear to neither eat nor drink until they kill Paul (vv. 12–14; evidently these men either die from starvation or break their oath!). They are upset with Paul over his teaching concerning Jesus and the Mosaic law, yet they themselves will not blink to break the law at any point to murder Paul, even going so far as to encourage a miscarriage of justice (v. 15), which the council agrees to pursue (v. 20). This is not simply the action of a group of outlying radicals but an orchestrated assassination attempt with the support and blessing of some, perhaps most, of the Jewish authorities. Some of the elders may have refused (cf. Luke's language in 23:14 with that in 22:30), especially among the Pharisees—consider how some Pharisees warned Jesus that Herod Antipas wanted to kill him (Luke 13:31), the Pharisees Nicodemus and Joseph of Arimathea supported Jesus in the Gospel of John, Gamaliel the Pharisee has previously urged moderation in dealing with Christians (Acts 5:33–40), and Acts 15:5 mentions "believers who belonged to the party of the Pharisees." However, these are clearly in the minority.

However the events work out behind the scenes, it is clear that opposition to Paul from his Jewish countrymen reaches its climax here in the narrative. At this point his nephew enters the scene (23:16; we know nothing about Paul's family apart from this text). The exchange between Paul, his nephew, and the tribune is straightforward (vv. 18–22). It is not clear how the nephew knows of the plot against Paul, but what *is* clear is that once again God providentially provides Paul a way out of danger. It is likely that by this time the tribune and the other local Roman authorities have little trust in the Jewish leaders and their charges against Paul. They take the threat to Paul's life seriously and are determined to keep this Roman citizen safe from harm.

The tribune is so concerned to protect Paul that at 9:00 p.m. he sends a large portion (more than half) of the military force from Jerusalem to accompany Paul to Antipatris, and from there seventy horsemen take him the rest of the way to Caesarea (vv. 23–24, 31–32). The tribune sends a letter with the armed guard to explain the situation to Felix. Luke makes clear that his account is not an exact quotation of the letter but a summary received from Paul or another source (v. 25). The letter essentially provides an account that explains why the tribune is sending Paul to Felix. The tribune reports he rescued Paul from the Jews because he discovered that Paul was a Roman citizen (v. 27). This is true, from a certain point of view. The letter condenses the story and omits how Lysias discovered Paul's citizenship only after his soldiers were ready to interrogate him with whips when Paul brought the subject up himself (22:23–24). It is absolutely true that Lysias did save Paul from certain death from the mob and then later when he heard about the assassination plot. Most importantly, he tells Felix that Paul comes to him with no official charges against him other than from an intramural Jewish squabble over their law.

The tribune's actions serve both to shift responsibility for Paul to the governor and to ensure that Paul remains safe from his Jewish countrymen, while also fulfilling the Lord's promise to Paul that he will testify in Rome (23:11). At the end of chapter 23, Paul stands before Felix, who, satisfied that Paul is under his jurisdiction (vv. 34–35), agrees to hear him once his Jewish accusers arrive. Caesarea will be Paul's home for the next two years.

#### *Response*

Paul's imprisonment—which covers the rest of Acts from this point—is not the script that any one of us would write for history's greatest missionary and theologian. If ever we need evidence that God's ways are not our ways, that his judgments are unsearchable and his paths beyond what we can trace (Rom. 11:33), we need go no further than a plain reading of Acts. The text in Romans just alluded to is Paul's conclusion upon reflecting and teaching on the inclusion of the Gentiles alongside the rejection and ultimate return of Jews who will believe in Jesus as Messiah. Who but God would have planned it like that?

We ought to practice putting ourselves in the story. It is worth taking time to consider just what it must have been like for the early Christians—particularly all those who begged Paul, in tears, not to go to Jerusalem—to hear what happened there as Paul was imprisoned. They would not have taken the events with the matter-of-fact nonchalance that comes from historical familiarity. As modern readers who know the story, we have to work at regaining and maintaining a sense of awe as we read a story that we ourselves would never have written. Paul had Jesus' promises and believed them, of course, and one of Luke's goals is to show God's relentless faithfulness to his promises and mission—and we are right to emphasize such considerations. Yet we should also consider the unsearchable wisdom of God, whose plan in Acts is nothing like what we would devise, nor likely what the early Christians expected.

1Or *weary* 2Some manuscripts add *and we would have judged him according to our law. 7But the chief captain Lysias came and with great violence took him out of our hands, 8commanding his accusers to come before you*.

## *Section Overview: Paul before Felix*

Ananias and his henchmen come from Jerusalem and accuse Paul of being the leader of the "sect of the Nazarenes," causing riots—which would get Felix's attention—and profaning the temple (Acts 24:5–6). Paul in turn openly affirms that he is indeed a follower of "the Way" and as such is, in fact, a true follower of the Jewish Law and Prophets (vv. 14–15). He flatly denies being responsible for riots or profaning the temple (v. 18). Felix has Paul put under protective custody (v. 23).

Felix is sympathetic with Paul, and on many occasions for two years he and his wife listen to Paul speak of what it means to be Christian. Felix is not, however, Paul's ally. He keeps the apostle imprisoned, pleasing the Jews, and hopes for a financial kickback from Paul. At the end of the two years Felix is replaced by Festus (vv. 24–27).

### *Section Outline*

- II.E. Paul before Felix (24:1–27)
	- 1. Paul Makes His Case (24:1–21)
	- 2. Paul Remains in Custody (24:22–27)

# *Comment*

24:1–21 *Paul Makes His Case.* Ananias brings along a spokesman, something like a prosecuting attorney, named Tertullus. His name may indicate a Gentile background, but he could simply be a Jew with a Greek name. His tone and words are full of flattery. He thanks Felix for the peace and reforms the Jews enjoy under his rule. Felix's tenure as governor was, in fact, hardly peaceful, and he was disliked by the Jews. Tertullus is doing what any lawyer would do to gain a judge's favor, but his introduction compares unfavorably to Paul's respectful and forthright address in verse 10, in which the apostle acknowledges Felix as governor and expresses gratitude for the chance to defend himself against the charges (cf. 26:2–3, 25–29).

When Paul was before the Jewish council, the interaction broke down over the issue of the resurrection. Thus Paul will claim that he is really on trial over that issue. But Tertullus brings three charges against Paul: (1) he starts riots everywhere (v. 5), (2) he is a leader of a sect called the "Nazarenes" (v. 5), and (3) he profaned the temple (v. 6). The third charge reflects the accusation in 21:28 that Paul teaches against the temple, Moses, and the Jewish people. According to Tertullus he was doing this very thing in Jerusalem when the Jews subdued him. Paul's reply comes in the next paragraph, but it is already clear from the text that there is no evidence for the charge. The first charge is equally baseless. Paul has seen several riots, and though he may have been the cause for rioting, whether in Ephesus, Corinth, or Jerusalem, he has not instigated or fomented uprisings. In every case he has been the innocent victim of violent men who would have killed him if the various governing authorities in each place had not intervened.

Concerning the second charge, this is the first time that Luke records an official recognition, and an implied condemnation, of the "sect of the Nazarenes." They are called Nazarenes because their leader is Jesus of Nazareth, whom their opponents believe to be a messianic pretender and enemy of the Jewish nation who died on a Roman cross. Tertullus is not simply naming the sect but charging Paul with leading it. This is yet another example (cf. 18:1–17) of how Christianity is not yet viewed, even by the Jews, as an independent religion. To the Jews, the Nazarenes are a wayward group of heretics following a false, dead messiah; they are wayward enough to be wiped out like their leader. Of the three charges, Paul willingly accepts only this one as true (24:14–15), and he will take its implications even further than the charges. Tertullus is so confident in his ironclad case that he is sure that Felix's questioning of Paul will bear out its truth (v. 8). The other Jews present at the trial unsurprisingly affirm all of the charges (v. 9).

Paul, unlike Tertullus, does not pander to Felix but simply acknowledges his authority to judge the case (v. 10). Paul's defense can be summarized in eight points, all of which he affirms can be verified:

- 1. I went to the temple to worship, a fact easily verified (v. 11).
- 2. I was neither arguing nor causing trouble (v. 12).
- 3. The Jews have no proof of the charges (v. 13).
- 4. I am a follower of "the Way," which they call a "sect" (vv. 14–15).
- 5. I came to Jerusalem with a gift and offerings (v. 17).
- 6. I was purified in the temple when they found me (v. 18).
- 7. The Jews from Asia who stirred up trouble are not here now (vv. 18–19).
- 8. My accusers know the only issue is the resurrection of the dead (vv. 15, 20–21).

These eight points are self-explanatory, but a few deserve special notice. For one, Paul admits that he is, in fact, a follower of "the Way," though he does not use all of the terms of his accusers. He asserts that "the Way" is the way of worshiping God that stands in the line of the patriarchs, the Law, and the Prophets (v. 14). In other words, the Jesus followers are the heirs of the promises. The implication is that the so-called sect is in reality the faithful community of the people of God. Paul then returns to the issue of resurrection—the point he maintains as the only reason for the trial. Paul reveals the presence of Pharisees at the trial ("these men"; v. 15)—thus it appears that representatives from both groups from the council are present—though it is unclear if these are the same men who found no reason to prosecute Paul (23:9).

Another point to highlight is Paul's biblical observation that the Jews from Asia who originally accused him of wrongdoing and were responsible for stirring everyone up in the first place (21:27) should be at the trial in person. This point surely gets Felix's attention and just as importantly underscores the biblical principle requiring witnesses for prosecution (Deut. 17:6; 19:15; cf. Heb. 10:28). But, since the Asian Jews are not there, Paul confronts the accusers that are present, asking in effect, "What, exactly, have I done wrong? The only reason I am here is because I preach the resurrection of the dead" (cf. Acts 24:20–21).

Paul is not referring to resurrection in the abstract or simply as a point of theological discussion. For him, the resurrection of the dead is specifically the resurrection of Jesus the Messiah, which foreshadows the resurrection of all believers. Paul is admitting in effect, "I am on trial here because I preach Jesus Christ crucified and risen from the dead. He is the true goal of the Law and the Prophets. In him God's resurrection promise is fulfilled. Only those who believe in him are faithful to God. True belief in the resurrection is belief in Jesus." In short, Paul is on trial for preaching the gospel; the resurrection he teaches is "according to the Way" (v. 14).

24:22–27 *Paul Remains in Custody.* Because Felix has "rather accurate knowledge of the Way"—that is, knowledge of Christian teaching—he delays judgment, telling Paul's accusers to wait until Lysias the tribune arrives (v. 22).93 Either Lysias never comes or Felix knows the Jews will eventually give up and go home. In either case, Paul spends the next two years under arrest in Caesarea. The imprisonment has certain freedoms, as Paul's friends are allowed to come and go (v. 23)—perhaps Paul's Roman citizenship earns him this right, or perhaps Felix understands Paul to be innocent of the accusations (even though he still has a vested interest in placating the Jews to some degree, thus keeping Paul in prison). The provision ensures that Paul's needs are seen to and is likely connected to Felix's hope that he will make money from the situation (v. 26).

Felix has enough interest to send for Paul, who speaks to him "about faith in Christ Jesus" (v. 24), specifically "righteousness and self-control and the coming judgment" (v. 25)—likely shorthand for the entire gospel. That is, "righteousness" refers to justification, or what it means to be saved, which undoubtedly includes the death and resurrection of Jesus; "self-control" is related to the promise of, and the living of, the Christian life through the Spirit; and "the coming judgment" is concerned with the warning of judgment for those who refuse, but also with hope for those who believe. No doubt Paul personalizes the message for Felix—perhaps in speaking of self-control he refers to or implies something about the questionable background of Felix's marriage to Drusilla, daughter of Herod Agrippa I (the king who put James to death and himself died an ignoble death during a remarkable

<sup>93</sup> We do not know how Felix had become familiar with Christian teaching, though it is possible that his Jewish wife, Drusilla, told him of the sect. Schnabel adds that with Judea under his jurisdiction, Felix would know about the followers of Jesus (*Acts*, 963). Schnabel also notes: "On a literary level, the comment shows Luke's readers that the favorable judgments of representatives of highest Roman officials about the Christians attesting their political innocuousness are grounded in fact."

display of pride and arrogance; 12:1–2, 20–23). Apparently Felix played a large part in arranging Drusilla's divorce from her first husband.94

Paul does not sugarcoat the gospel for Felix, who is "alarmed" by the message (24:25)—Paul's message gets his attention and disturbs him, leaving him unsettled, and so he sends Paul away. Luke's picture of Felix is of a man with at least mixed motives. He already has some knowledge of Christian beliefs and perhaps genuine curiosity to hear more from Paul. But he is also hoping for a bribe from Paul, presumably either to release him or to ensure his safety. Legally Felix cannot take bribes, but the practice was nevertheless rampant among Roman officials of the time. So it is possible that from the very start what he really saw was a chance to enrich himself. Most likely, however, Felix is interested both in Paul and his message and also in lining his own pockets. But any ulterior motive did not deter Paul from preaching the gospel.

The narrative of Felix in Acts ends with no response of repentance on his part. More than that, it ends on a note of injustice. Though he never explicitly states as much, Luke implies that Felix, like the tribune Lysias, believes Paul to be innocent of the charges brought by his accusers. At the same time, he is unwilling to release him. History shows that Felix struggled with keeping the peace during his tenure, and thus he seeks to pacify the Jews by keeping their enemy in jail. Paul remains in prison two years until a new governor, Porcius Festus, comes to Judea. This new governor will be willing to do what Felix is not—release Paul—but Paul himself will guarantee that this never happens. He is bound for Rome, and Festus becomes the means to that end.

### *Response*

Like Paul, we should look for every opportunity to share the gospel with whomever God puts in front of us at any given time. We should be especially aware when someone is *open* to hearing the gospel—not only when a person is genuinely interested in hearing what we have to say but in situations in which someone has, at best, mixed motives. Maybe he or she seeks to refute what we say, or perhaps desires to win us over to another view. The background, intentions, and motivations of others are of no consequence in regard to whether we share the gospel, but such factors should influence *how* we share. Regardless, we should seek to be clear and forthright with the complete message of the gospel—salvation in Christ, new life in Christ, hope in Christ.

Whether or not Drusilla's background was in Paul's mind as he shared with Felix, we should look for and be sensitive to specific areas of contact, behaviors, words, or beliefs that may serve as segues into personalized evangelism, specifically those areas that provide an opportunity to apply the reality of both condemnation and salvation in personal ways. To be saved is to be saved *from* something:

<sup>94</sup> As every major Acts commentary notes, the Jewish historian Josephus, in his *Antiquities of the Jews*, records how Drusilla, lured away by Felix, left her first husband, Gaius Julius Azizus, priest-king of Emesa. Felix is blamed for causing her to break the law.

sin. It is not enough to present the benefits of following Jesus. Following Jesus comes only through repentance and faith, and a gospel presentation must include the weight of condemnation and guilt that leads to hope in Christ. The more we can do this in personal, specific ways, rather than in vague, general ideas about sin, or evil, or hopelessness in the world (unless we plan on bringing those general principles to bear on a personal level), the more we present the real, biblical Jesus to people as their potential Savior who saves them from their sin and offers them hope.

1Greek *him*

#### *Section Overview: Paul Will Go to Caesar*

This chapter begins with Festus in Jerusalem and the Jews urging him to bring Paul back to Jerusalem (Acts 25:1–3). They are seeking not a trial but an opportunity to kill him. Festus asks the Jews to come to Caesarea if they have charges against Paul (v. 5). There they bring false charges against Paul, who denies all of them. They apparently also charge Paul with a crime that is sure to win the attention of the Roman authorities (as it did with Pontius Pilate): treason. In an attempt to pacify the Jews, Festus asks Paul if he desires to be tried in Jerusalem, but Paul again exercises his Roman rights (vv. 9–10). He knows what will happen in Jerusalem, so he appeals to Caesar (v. 11).

Festus relates Paul's story to King Agrippa and also notes that he considers Paul to be innocent of any charges that should concern Roman authorities. The issues are over Jewish religious issues and the resurrection of a man named Jesus. Once again, the differences between the Jews and Christians are seen by the authorities as in-house debates. Clearly, Festus is at a loss as to how to handle the situation. Agrippa decides he would like to hear Paul for himself. This chapter sets the stage for Paul's last recorded defense in Acts, in chapter 26. What appears to some as a minor religious dispute between a few Jews is actually the most important issue in the history of the world: the identity of Jesus of Nazareth.

#### *Section Outline*

- II.F. Paul Will Go to Caesar (25:1–27)
	- 1. Paul Appeals to Caesar (25:1–12)
	- 2. Festus Refers Paul to Agrippa (25:13–27)

### *Comment*

25:1–12 *Paul Appeals to Caesar.* Two years do nothing to lessen the Jewish leaders' hatred of Paul. On Festus's first trip to Jerusalem—only three days after his arrival to the area—the Jewish leaders immediately take up their case against Paul. Their motives have not changed at all: they want Paul brought to Jerusalem so that they can kill him (v. 3; cf. 23:12). Festus himself has not yet met or heard from Paul, and he is wise, or shrewd, enough not to go along with their terms. If they have something against Paul, they are welcomed to come to Caesarea and make their case. Later Luke notes that Festus desires to do a favor for the Jews (25:9; cf. 24:27), but not at the expense of compromising his own position and authority. The longstanding pattern of Gentile protection of Paul against the Jews continues with Festus, as God continues to make good on his promise to bring his Word to the ends of the earth.

It is clear that the Romans have more interest in upholding their own laws and practices than the Jewish authorities do in upholding the law of Moses. Granted, officials such as Gallio (18:12), the tribune Lysias (23:26), Felix, and Festus have a vested personal interest in upholding Roman law, and they are not above cutting corners (e.g., Felix's hope for a bribe). Nevertheless, they show far more loyalty to Rome than the Jewish leaders do to Moses and the covenant. The arrest and trial of Jesus was a previous example of this sad reality.

Verses 6–12 return to Caesarea, with Festus taking his place as judge. The Jews bring "many and serious charges" against Paul, but they have no evidence (v. 7). They stand around Paul making their accusations—we can imagine Paul standing calmly in their midst, with deep sadness (cf. Rom. 9:3), as they rant and rave with all of their false accusations, each baseless charge building up more evidence of their own rejection of the Messiah and the covenant God they claim to serve.

Luke does not quote the accusers this time—readers are already familiar with their charges. But he does include a brief report of Paul's reply that summarizes their case (Acts 25:8). Besides denying any crime against the law or the temple, Paul mentions a supposed wrongdoing unmentioned in the narrative since the uproar in Thessalonica (17:2–7): offense against Caesar. It is a fair assumption that these Jews have charged Paul with the same kind of treason alleged by the Jews in Thessalonica: "acting against the decrees of Caesar, saying that there is another king, Jesus" (17:7). The same issue is likely raised here. Perhaps Paul's Jewish opponents believe they have found a way to use his Roman citizenship against him. Rather than swearing allegiance to Caesar, Paul's allegiance is to Jesus of Nazareth, whom he calls King and Lord.

There is precedent for this charge. In the Gospels, the Pharisees and Herodians attempt to trap Jesus with a question concerning Caesar's authority (Matt. 22:17; cf. Mark 12:14; Luke 20:22). Likewise, the Jews apply pressure to the Roman governor Pilate by reminding him, "If you release this man, you are not Caesar's friend. Everyone who makes himself a king opposes Caesar" (John 19:12). The same Jews also cry, "We have no king but Caesar" (John 19:15)—an astonishing thing for a Jew to say, but one that provides readers of Acts insight into the depths of the Jewish rejection of Jesus and their subsequent rejection of his disciples. The Jewish leaders out to stop Paul are not faithful to Yahweh; they were unfaithful to him when they killed Jesus, just as their fathers were unfaithful when they persecuted his prophets (Matthew 23).

Festus's job is to keep the peace, but it becomes clear to Paul that he himself is in a potentially dangerous situation. Festus desires to do the Jews a favor (Acts 25:9; cf. Felix in 24:27), but he does not rule against Paul. Instead he asks him if he wants to make his case in Jerusalem. Paul chooses to invoke his citizenship instead, pointing out that he is right where he is supposed to be: at a Roman tribunal (25:11). He turns the issue back to Festus, pointing out that he knows Paul has not committed anything against the Jews (v. 10). In other words, this is purely a Roman matter, and he is quite willing to face the consequences if he is guilty of anything deserving of death in a Roman context.

Paul must sense that Festus is not above emulating Pontius Pilate and washing his hands of the whole situation. He points out that if he is not guilty regarding the Jews, then no one, not even Festus, can turn him over to them. His appeal to Caesar must have been completely unpredicted and absolutely stunning to Festus. Roman citizens had a right to appeal their cases all the way to the emperor. Luke does not record the Jews' response (no doubt they have objections), but he does note that the request is enough to force Festus to step aside and confer with his advisers. He returns to the proceedings in what is probably a mix of confusion (see 25:26) and perhaps, at least in the short term, relief. He does what he has to do as a Roman official: he grants Paul's request. With that, the direction of the rest of the narrative is set. The Jewish leaders and enemies are out of the picture for Paul. Paul's way was chosen by Christ Jesus, and the apostle to the Gentiles will be sent, under Gentile authority, to the very heart of the Gentile world. In one fell swoop, Paul sheds these accusers forever. The major point of tension in Acts, Jewish unbelief and opposition to the gospel, evaporates.

25:13–27 *Festus Refers Paul to Agrippa.* Herod Agrippa II, son of Agrippa I (12:1ff.), does not rule Judea, but he does have authority over the temple, including the authority to appoint priests. By this time the Romans have taken back Galilee, Perea, Samaria, Judea, and Idumea, all of which were under the rule of Agrippa I at one time.95 Agrippa II is, nevertheless, still quite powerful and influential and, more importantly, "familiar with all the customs and controversies of the Jews" (26:3). When he and his sister Bernice come to Caesarea, Festus wastes no time recounting the recent events. Festus may no longer have to worry about the Jews, but he does not want to send Paul to the emperor without explanation (25:26–27). He lays out the history of the case, careful to show both that he has done everything by the book (vv. 15–17) and also that Paul's accusers have brought baseless charges. They have simply argued over points of the Jewish religion and the man Jesus, whom some say is dead even though Paul claims he is alive (v. 19). Festus recounts how Paul declined to go to Jerusalem but appealed to Caesar instead (vv. 20–21).

Although Gentile rulers and authorities are the means of saving Paul on a number of occasions throughout Acts, they never know quite what to make of him. Felix had an interest in him, including hope for profit, but he left Paul in limbo, never reaching a conclusion in his case. Likewise, Festus clearly does not know what to do with Paul. He had attempted to shift responsibility for him to the Jews, but Paul halted that attempt by appealing to Caesar. His confusion over Paul continues as he seeks help from Agrippa. What every Gentile authority in the book of Acts recognizes, however, is that whatever the charges, Paul is innocent of anything deserving of death. Kings, rulers, and authorities at various levels see this all as a dispute between a few Jews, but in reality it is a dispute over loyalty to the true King, Jesus of Nazareth.

Agrippa apparently has the same flair for pomp and circumstance that his father had (and died over). Dignitaries and military personnel assemble—the most powerful and influential people in that region of the empire—and Paul is ushered in (v. 23). He stands and listens as Festus both repeats the events that have led to this moment (vv. 24–25) and also reveals the real reason he wants Agrippa to hear the case: Festus now has the responsibility to send a prisoner, a Roman citizen who has appealed to Caesar, to the emperor, and he does not want to do so without a legitimate charge (vv. 26–27).

## *Response*

As Christians, those who believe in Jesus the Jewish Messiah, we must always take care over the way we speak of "the Jews" in the NT, particularly in the Gospels and Acts. The unbelief of the Jews, their OT history and NT continuance of rejection and rebellion against God, is a reflection of the hearts of all Gentiles as well. Paul makes this point in Romans 3:19–20: the experience of the Jews under the law provides public evidence that no one is righteous. The law's condemning function is on full display in the OT, as those with the law cannot and will not keep it. This is how the law leaves everyone in the world speechless, without defense. I could summarize it this way: "See how Israel broke the law continually? See their idolatry in the face of a God who reveals himself and his promises? See their rejection of their Messiah? We would do the same."

1Or *the Hebrew dialect* (probably Aramaic) 2Or *In a short time you would persuade me to act like a Christian!*

#### *Section Overview: Paul before King Agrippa: Who Is True to the Covenant?*

Paul is glad to speak before Agrippa, since he is "familiar with all the customs and controversies of the Jews" (Acts 26:3). This chapter contains the most extensive testimony from Paul in Acts. As in his defense at Jerusalem, Paul mentions his personal background and presents himself—and, by extension, the Christian faith—as the proper expression of the Jewish religion. Again he emphasizes the resurrection, the issue at the heart of the charges against Paul. He then recounts how he himself was once a persecutor of the followers of Jesus, implying that his former actions were wrong in the same way that his accusers' now are (vv. 4–11).

Paul next recounts his conversion; what Luke includes here is not quite the same as the earlier accounts in Acts, though there are no contradictions. One striking difference is how Paul tells Agrippa that Jesus sent him to turn the Gentiles "from the power of Satan to God" for forgiveness (v. 18), affirming the equal place Gentiles have in the people of God. This is the main issue: Paul's teaching on the resurrection includes a message to and about the Gentiles that his enemies cannot accept.

Paul goes on to tell Agrippa that he preached in obedience to Jesus first in Damascus, then to Jerusalem, Judea, and finally to the Gentiles. Paul's ministry is itself a fulfillment of Jesus' original commission in 1:8. He has faithfully preached only what Moses and the prophets prophesied. This is the reason the Jewish authorities want him dead (26:19–21).

The chapter ends with Paul appealing to the king to "become such as I am except for these chains" (v. 29). As for the secular authorities and King Agrippa, they find Paul innocent of all charges. If he had not appealed to Caesar, he could be set free. As it stands, Paul will travel to Rome, the journey Jesus promised over two years before (23:11).

# *Section Outline*

II.G. Paul before King Agrippa: Who Is True to the Covenant? (26:1–32)

- 1. Paul Introduces Himself (26:1–8)
- 2. Paul Testifies (26:9–23)
- 3. True and Rational Words (26:24–32)

# *Comment*

26:1–8 *Paul Introduces Himself.* Agrippa knows more about Jewish issues than have Paul's previous interlocutors, so the apostle provides a more detailed account of his conversion—which explains why this version of Paul's testimony differs at some points from his former accounts in Acts. This text is also a fulfillment of Jesus' words to Ananias at the time of Paul's conversion: "He is a chosen instrument of mine to carry my name before the Gentiles and kings and the children of Israel" (9:15). Paul has been witnessing to everyone in every place since that time, but each of the three groups singled out by Christ are present in the context beginning in chapter 22. Paul spoke before Israelites in Jerusalem (chs. 22–23), the Gentiles Felix and Festus (chs. 24–25), and now King Agrippa.

As he does in Galatians 1:13–14 and Philippians 3:4–6, Paul recounts his Pharisaic history. He does so here in order to set up an ironic point: his accusers know full well who he is, where he came from, and what his religious background includes. He was a Pharisee and now is on trial for what all Pharisees believe: resurrection (Acts 26:4–7). Why should his accusers be so shocked that God raises the dead, since they all believe in resurrection (v. 8)?

Paul is aware, of course—as are readers of Acts—that the real point (except for the Sadducees) is not whether there is a resurrection but that Paul preaches the resurrection of Jesus from Nazareth, which establishes him as the Messiah. It is not, furthermore, simply that God raised Jesus but that Jesus is the fulfillment of all the hopes and promises of Israel. It is *this* resurrection that is at issue. For Paul there is no distinction between believing in a resurrection and proclaiming Jesus; he is the resurrection, the hope of the twelve tribes of Israel (v. 7). Essentially, Paul is on trial for believing in and being faithful to God.

26:9–23 *Paul Testifies.* Paul's next testimony could be broken down into three parts:

- 1. What I was (vv. 9–11)
- 2. What changed (vv. 12–18)
- 3. What I now am (vv. 19–23)

The differences between this description of Paul's conversion and his testimony before the Jews in chapter 22 or the original account in chapter 9 are neither troublesome nor surprising. Everyone tells a story differently depending on the

audience, circumstances, and context: certain details are left out or added; others are expanded or shortened; timespans expand or contract. Further, a literary setting such as Acts offers a narrated account, not an audio recording.

Besides adding the minor detail that everyone fell to the ground when the light from heaven appeared, Paul also mentions that the voice was in "Hebrew"—probably the Aramaic dialect (cf. ESV mg.; 22:2)—and included a proverb (26:14). Paul does not mention the language to find corroboration from other witnesses, who did not "understand the voice" (22:9). Perhaps he mentions it to explain his other name, Saul,96 or to underscore that his encounter was with the Lord of *Israel*.

The maxim Jesus cites refers to the sharp stick (goad) that ox drivers use to keep oxen under control. By application, Paul can no longer fight against or resist God. Why the phrase is left out of the other accounts is unknown, but there is no reason to doubt its authenticity. Paul was not a faithful Pharisee doing his lawful duty until he came to find Jesus to be the answer and the fulfillment of every OT promise. Paul did not shift allegiance to a new or better or clearer revelation of God; he was converted from a life of revolt against God to membership in the people of God by faith in Jesus Christ. No one who rejects the Messiah is a faithful member of the covenant, old or new.

Paul is on trial for his belief in resurrection, and he provides an extended account of his encounter with the risen Jesus. Luke picks up an undercurrent that goes back explicitly at least to chapter 22 and implicitly throughout Acts. Paul may be on trial over the resurrection, but close to the heart of the matter is his relationship to the Gentiles (26:17, 20–21). In 21:28–29 the Jews from Asia accused Paul of defiling the temple by bringing Greeks inside, having seen Trophimus with him in Jerusalem. Paul's dealings with the Gentiles were hardly secret. Not only does he teach that Jesus rose from the dead and is the Jewish Messiah; he is the Messiah for the Gentiles as well. It is not surprising that the Jews never mention their agitation over Paul's association with Gentiles when they bring charges against Paul before Gentile authorities.

Paul was appointed to witness to the revelation he received, and would receive, in Jesus (26:16), specifically as a witness to the Gentiles (v. 17). Paul chooses to mention that in his commissioning Jesus promised to deliver him from the Jews and send him to the Gentiles—the very thing now happening in the narrative. Paul's account is reminiscent of his epistles as well as themes from the Gospels. "Turn from darkness to light" (v. 18) is similar to his reminding the Ephesians, "You were darkness, but now you are light in the Lord" (Eph. 5:8). He tells the Thessalonians, "You are all children of light, children of the day. We are not of the night or of the darkness" (1 Thess. 5:5).

This also connects to a theme found in Luke's Gospel, in which Elizabeth is told that her son (John the Baptist) will be a prophet of God, who will soon "give light to those who sit in darkness and in the shadow of death" (Luke 1:79). A year or so later, Simeon will pick up the baby Jesus and declare him to be a "light for revelation to the Gentiles" (Luke 2:32). This light for the Gentiles is also "for glory to your people Israel" (Luke 2:32), the very point Paul will make in Acts 26:23: Jesus is for both Jews and Gentiles.

Deliverance from Satan (v. 18) is not a common theme in Acts, but in the context of the book, Jesus' commission describes bringing the Gentiles from the kingdom of Satan to the kingdom of God. Coming to Jesus means leaving one realm for another. Satan and his activity are common Pauline themes.97 Colossians 1:13–20 ties the themes of this passage together. There Paul speaks of God's rescuing us "from the domain of darkness" and moving us "to the kingdom of his beloved Son" (Col. 1:13). This exchange of kingdoms is linked to forgiveness (v. 14) and reconciliation of all people to God through the blood of Christ (v. 20).

Jesus' commission next mentions forgiveness and inheritance for the Gentiles (Acts 26:18), which go hand in hand. Paul ties these themes together in his own ministry in multiple places, nowhere more thoroughly than in Ephesians 1:7–14. There he makes clear that forgiveness in the sight of God is through Christ's work, and through that work both Jews and Gentiles have an equal share in the blessings of God in Christ.

Finally, Jesus mentions "those who are sanctified by faith in me" (Acts 26:18). Here "sanctified" is used as a summary of salvation, not in a systematic sense but in the sense specifically of being forgiven (which is itself frequently used in the Bible as a summary for the whole work of salvation; cf. Acts 20:32; Rom. 15:16; 1 Cor. 1:2; 6:11; Eph. 5:26; Heb. 2:11). Although believers tend to emphasize progressive sanctification, that is, the ongoing work of God to conform believers to Jesus through various means, here the word refers clearly to a status already given: those who "are sanctified." Today we are also accustomed, moreover, to the doctrine of justification by faith but rarely speak of *sanctification* by faith. Faith is no less the instrument in sanctification than it is in justification. "Sanctified" here refers to the people of God who by faith are forgiven, delivered from Satan's kingdom, and brought into God's kingdom. The phrase is not an abstracted theological point, and to treat it as such misses the author's intention. The dramatic point is that the Gentiles are included; they have full inheritance among God's people (cf. Acts 10:44–48; 11:17; 15:7–11; Rom. 4:9–12; 11:11–12, 25; Gal. 3:7–9; Eph. 3:6). And they have all of this through believing in Jesus: the people of God are defined by allegiance to him.

Paul's recounting of his encounter with the resurrected Jesus sends a clear message. All along he has asserted that he *does* in fact follow Moses, he *does* believe the promises, and he *is* faithful to God and the covenant. As was Saul of Tarsus, Paul's *accusers* are the ones resisting and rejecting God by refusing to believe in Jesus. They are the ones who ultimately reject the resurrection because the promise of

Christians must be on guard lest they be led astray by Satan (1 Cor. 7:5; 2 Cor. 2:11). Satan is an active enemy (2 Cor. 12:7; 1 Thess. 2:18) who has led people astray and continues to do so (2 Cor. 11:14; 2 Thess. 2:9; 1 Tim. 5:15). Paul speaks of turning over to Satan unrepentant sinners and those who reject the apostolic gospel and authority (1 Cor. 5:5; 1 Tim. 1:20).

resurrection is fulfilled in Jesus. They are the ones who kick against the goads. Their outrage over Paul's dealings with the Gentiles is further proof of their disbelief in the God they claim to know. Paul describes the Jews in Judea who cause trouble for the Jerusalem church and the apostles in particular in 1 Thessalonians 2:15–16: "[They] killed both the Lord Jesus and the prophets, and drove us out, and displease God and oppose all mankind by hindering us from speaking to the Gentiles that they might be saved—so as always to fill up the measure of their sins. But wrath has come upon them at last!"

This theme of true faithfulness to God continues in Acts 26:19. Because of the encounter on the Damascus road, Paul obeyed; the "heavenly vision" of the Lord convinced Paul that the revelation was a direct word from God. Once again, it is clear that Paul was not simply becoming a better Jew or finally getting on board with God's plan. Rather, he experienced a true conversion from unbelief and disobedience to faith and obedience—he was saved. The rest of the account underscores this truth by showing Paul's bearing the fruit of true repentance. What Paul says about the Gentiles in the following verses proves the point.

Paul personally participated in the fulfillment of Jesus' commission to the disciples in 1:8. From Damascus, he headed to Jerusalem, through Judea, and to the Gentiles. His description is brief and to the point: he pressed people to repent, turn to God, and perform "deeds in keeping with their repentance" (26:20). The allusion to John the Baptist's message to the Jews is unmistakable (Luke 3:8). The same word John preached to the Jews in preparation for the Messiah is preached to the Gentiles after the resurrection of the Messiah. Everyone, including Jews, Paul, and the Gentiles, must repent and believe in Jesus and show their new (covenant) relationship through obedience to him. Repentance and obedience to Jesus demonstrate who is loyal to God. Although resurrection has been at the center of the discussion since Paul stood before the Jews (Acts 23:6), the underlying issue is that faithfulness to God means accepting Jesus as Lord. That was why the Jews took Paul and attempted to kill him (26:20–21).

Paul underscored the reality of Jesus as the fulfillment of all that had come before by standing in front of everyone, both "small and great," proclaiming exactly what "the prophets and Moses said would come to pass" (vv. 22–23). The reference to "small and great" evokes Jeremiah's new covenant prophecy that when the Spirit came, all would know the Lord: "No longer shall each one teach his neighbor and each his brother, saying, 'Know the Lord,' for they shall all know me, from the least of them to the greatest, declares the Lord. For I will forgive their iniquity, and I will remember their sin no more" (Jer. 31:34).

Paul, like the other disciples, knows Jesus, including his suffering and resurrection, as the fulfillment of the Scripture (e.g., Acts 2:25, 34; 3:18, 21–25; 10:43; 15:15; 24:14). These references also provide a summary of the gospel sketch Paul offers in 1 Corinthians 15:1–4, which also features the promise-fulfillment motif. The connection to 1 Corinthians 15, and Paul's theology generally, is evident from Paul's conclusion as he connects Christ's resurrection and the proclamation of the gospel (Acts 26:23) and also alludes again to his birth narrative: "Being the first to rise from the dead, [Jesus] would proclaim light both to our people and to the Gentiles" (v. 23).

26:24–32 *True and Rational Words.* The gospel is life to those who believe but death to those who reject it (2 Cor. 2:16). Festus clearly wants nothing to do with Paul's gospel. His reaction is similar to those in Athens who called Paul a "babbler" (Acts 17:18). Festus's charge that Paul is "out of your mind" is met with a virtual quote of 2 Corinthians (in content, if not in terminology): he is both sane and speaking "true and rational words" (Acts 26:25), which is remarkably similar to Paul's claim that "if we are beside ourselves, it is for God" (2 Cor. 5:13). Paul is not claiming to present a "rationalistic" argument of proofs or asserting that his message rests on its pure rationality. Rather, Paul's experience, his gospel ministry, and his defense "agree with the rationality of human reason"98—that is, they are "reasonable." The gospel Paul preaches is not "rational" in the sense that to believe or accept anything else is, therefore, irrational. This is not a battle of apologetic wits.

While it could be argued that it is God who defines what is "rational," or that the gospel is the true, rational message, Paul is not making a subtle stab at secular definitions of rationality or logical coherence, though his message does challenge unbelieving worldviews. It does so, however, not simply by proving counter worldviews to be wrong but through conviction, condemnation, and subsequent hope (cf. Peter's sermon at Pentecost in Acts 2, for instance). The reasonable nature of Paul's defense is the wisdom of God (1 Cor. 1:18–31), which to Festus seems foolish.

The evangelistic intent of Paul's speech is explicit when he turns to address Agrippa. Paul knows Agrippa is aware both of the events that have taken place in Israel and also of the teaching of the Bible (Acts 26:26). Is Paul taking a chance on Agrippa's being, deep down, a believer in God? Agrippa is a Gentile but is closely tied to Judaism.99 Regardless of Paul's estimation of Agrippa's spiritual state, he equates believing in the prophets with believing in Jesus (v. 27). In other words, if one truly believes the old covenant prophets—the prophets of the messiah—then one should believe Jesus, who fulfills the promise of the prophets. Again, this is not a defense in the sense that Paul is arguing his case in hopes of being found not guilty and then being set free. The die is cast: he is going to Rome, and so he takes this opportunity to carry out the commission Jesus has had in store for Paul from the beginning: "to carry my name before the Gentiles and kings and the children of Israel" (9:15).

Agrippa fully understands that Paul is pressing him to believe. But instead of answering the question, he asks one of his own. There is considerable discussion concerning how the Greek text of 26:28 should be rendered. "In a short time" could be translated as "with so little effort" or "with so few words," but Paul's

<sup>98</sup> Schnabel, *Acts*, 1015.

<sup>99</sup> Peterson, *Acts*, 674.

reply in verse 29 ("whether short or long") seems best understood as a response to "in a short time." The point is that Agrippa knows Paul is hoping to persuade him to be a Christian. The term "Christian" appears only one other time in Acts (cf. 11:26), where it was presumably coined by unbelievers at Antioch. Its usage by Agrippa perhaps implies that, unlike most in the narrative, he understands there to be a distinction between the followers of Jesus and the Jews, although this cannot be proved.

It is fitting that Paul's last extended speech in Acts concludes with an appeal to all. He desires all to believe as he does, and also hopes that all will be spared his suffering ("except for these chains"; 26:29). Agrippa confirms the judgment of other officials: Paul has done nothing wrong and deserves to be set free (v. 31). But he has appealed to Caesar, and there is no going back (v. 32).

Many commentators and interpreters highlight the parallels between Jesus' inevitable trip to Jerusalem and Paul's inevitable trip to Rome. Luke is clearly depicting Paul as following in Jesus' footsteps, presenting Paul in his own "passion." But the primary reason he recounts Paul's experiences in chapters 21 and following is because this is exactly how it happened. In this account we see God's hand of providence guiding Paul to fulfill the apostolic commission to take the gospel to the ends of the earth—a trajectory that spans the narrative from beginning to end.

#### *Response*

Paul preaches the gospel in any situation and to any person, regardless of social standing, power, or education. Clearly, in God's providence, Paul is the exact man for the job. Luke, however, highlights not Paul's education or gifts but his simple and direct manner of speaking about his experience and the truth of Christ. Paul is not ashamed to speak about the resurrection to the highly educated in Athens or to men in authority. He is unafraid to be called a "babbler" or "insane"; he wants only to preach Christ. This does not mean that Paul is superhuman or the only man since Jesus never to feel fear or hesitation at the prospect of witnessing. Paul knows his weaknesses (2 Cor. 11:29–30), but more importantly he knows that it is precisely his weaknesses that make the gospel shine brighter (2 Cor. 12:10; 13:4).

Paul believes, further, that the simple words of the gospel are power and truth (Rom. 1:16–17; 1 Cor. 2:4). Believers can spend too much time worried that someone might make fun of them, reject them, or beat them in an argument. We should stop worrying — we *will* be made fun of, rejected, and beaten in arguments. The pressure is removed when we stop fretting and realize the inevitable. For many believers around the world, the stakes are much higher, putting such considerations to shame. Whoever and wherever we are, the gospel we preach is able to save everyone, from family members to friends or strangers, from enemies to people in the highest positions of power. We cannot wait until we no longer fear or feel embarrassed—we would wait forever before such emotions disappeared. We must also ignore demographic studies about when, how, or at what age people are likely to believe. Such observations may be interesting reflections, but they are often completely useless otherwise. We ought to be like Paul, living fully in and understanding our context and those around us. We must live a life that reflects our belief in Jesus, sharing him with everyone we can, fearing no one but God.
